title: Troubleshooting Dropped Stitches: Prevention and Quick Fixes
author: Sue Jalowiec
excerpt: Dropped stitches don't have to ruin your project. Learn how to prevent them and fix them quickly when they happen.
description: Dropped stitches don't have to ruin your project. Learn how to prevent them and fix them quickly when they happen.
body:
Every machine knitter has faced the dreaded dropped stitch. Whether you're a beginner or experienced knitter, understanding why stitches drop and how to fix them quickly can save your projects and your sanity.

Why Stitches Drop

Dropped stitches happen when a loop slips off a needle and starts to ladder down through your fabric. Common causes include:

  • Tension too tight or too loose — Improper tension is the #1 cause
  • Damaged needles — Bent or worn needle latches don't close properly
  • Yarn catching — Snagging on the carriage or gates
  • Rushing the carriage — Moving too fast doesn't allow latches to close
  • Old or poor quality yarn — Weak or slubby yarn can break or slip

Prevention Strategies

1. Check Your Tension

Proper tension is critical. Your yarn should feed smoothly without being too tight (which stresses the needles) or too loose (which creates sloppy stitches that slip off easily).

2. Inspect Your Needles Regularly

Run your finger along the needle bed. Feel for needles that are:

  • Bent or raised higher than others
  • Stuck in position
  • Have damaged latches

Replace problem needles immediately—they're not expensive and they'll save you hours of frustration.

3. Move the Carriage Smoothly

Consistent, steady carriage movement gives needle latches time to close properly. Jerky or rushed movements are a recipe for dropped stitches.

Quick Fix: The Latch Tool Method

When you catch a dropped stitch early, you can fix it in seconds:

  1. Stop knitting immediately — Don't move the carriage
  2. Locate the dropped stitch — It will be at the bottom of a ladder
  3. Insert your latch tool through the loop from front to back
  4. Hook the first ladder bar and pull it through the loop
  5. Repeat up the ladder until you reach the needle
  6. Place the stitch back on the needle — Make sure the latch is closed
Important: Always work from the bottom (dropped stitch) up to the top (current row). Working backwards will twist your stitches.

When the Damage Is Severe

If a stitch has laddered down more than 10-15 rows, or if you didn't notice it right away, you have options:

  • Partial unraveling — Take the work off the machine, unravel to the problem area, and rehang
  • Duplicate stitch repair — For small areas, you can hand-stitch over the dropped section
  • Embrace it — In textured or lace patterns, a small irregularity may not be noticeable

Practice Makes Perfect

Drop a stitch intentionally on a practice swatch. Practice picking it up with your latch tool until the motion becomes automatic. When it happens on a real project, you'll be ready!

Remember: Even the most experienced knitters drop stitches occasionally. The difference is knowing how to fix them quickly and move on.
